See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest import config from tempest import test import testtools from manila_tempest_tests.tests.api import base CONF = config.CONF class AvailabilityZonesTest(base.BaseSharesTest): def _list_availability_zones_assertions(self, availability_zones): self.assertTrue(len(availability_zones) > 0) keys = ("created_at", "updated_at", "name", "id") for az in availability_zones: self.assertEqual(len(keys), len(az)) for key in keys: self.assertIn(key, az) @test.attr(type=["smoke", "gate"]) @testtools.skipUnless( float(CONF.share.max_api_microversion) > 2.6, "Microversion '2.7' is required. " "But maximum is set to '%s'." % CONF.share.max_api_microversion) def test_list_availability_zones_core_api(self): azs = self.shares_v2_client.list_availability_zones(version="2.7") self._list_availability_zones_assertions(azs) @test.attr(type=["smoke", "gate"]) def test_list_availability_zones_extension(self): # NOTE(vponomaryov): remove this test with removal of availability zone # extension. azs = self.shares_client.list_availability_zones() self._list_availability_zones_assertions(azs)

commit_message:
Migration state machine

Implement a state machine to manage migration status.

Change-Id: I01fc9ac167e251b299b72c96ffeca483f51ac68c
Implements: blueprint migration-state-machine
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/69/235169/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================================== Migration state machine ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/migration-state-machine Implement a state machine to manage migration status. Problem description =================== In the current code, migration statuses (Migration.status) are represented with pure String. So are image, snapshot and event statuses. It has the following demerits: 1. When we grep the code for migration statuses, we could get lots of noisy info we don't want. eg. When we want to grep migration status 'error', all the other statuses will also come out. 2. Sometimes, we use '' to wrap a string, but sometimes using "". So usually we need to grep twice for more precise results. eg. Grep "'migrating'" and "\"migrating\"". I found that in some test files, " " is used, but in other files, ' ' is used. 3. People could spell the string incorrectly, or give a different word to represent the same meaning. eg. In the current code, we have three statuses representing the migration is over: finished, completed and done. I really cannot tell the difference among them. To prevent above problems, Nikola suggested to implement a state machine to manage migration status. And we can reuse the common state machine builder in openstack/automaton. (https://review.openstack.org/203284) Use Cases ---------- 1. The migration status will be more clear to users. Only one human readable string for each status. 2. Using a state machine API to maintain the status is more reliable than pure string. 3. Once the state machine is correctly defined, the state modification won't miss. It is more reliable than human modification. Proposed change =============== 1. Define all 16 migration statuses as enum instead of pure string. 2. Implement a migration state machine for migration status, reusing state machine builder in openstack/automaton. 3. Use the state machine to change migration status when necessary. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Tang Chen (tangchen@cn.fujitsu.com) Work Items ---------- * Define all 16 migration statuses as enum. * Implement a state machine for migration. * Use the state machine to modify migration status. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/197668/ [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/197669/ [3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/203284/ [4] http://paste.openstack.org/show/384853/

commit_message:
Update overcloud template description and Count constraints

Currently there's a vague list of services in the description, so instead
describe the roles supported for deployment, and encode the minimum allowed
of one Controller/Compute with zero Storage nodes in the parameter constraints.

Change-Id: Ib4917843f3e4770f0260db72719ed6af0ee8dc13

commit_message:
Allow setting custom ec2api port to listen to

The README mentions that install.sh allows setting
custom port(other than 8788 default) to start ec2api
on but upon looking, there wasnt any option. This patch
adds the option to allow user to set a different port
prior to installation using install.sh script.
also the options defined in devstack plugin but
it isnt being set in ec2api.conf.

Change-Id: I440b69fafb5555a7a9f4d1e27b1f811d2a3ecc29
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/17/237817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: EC2API_PORT=8788PUBLIC_URL=${OS_AUTH_URL%:*}:"$EC2API_PORT"/iniset $CONF_FILE DEFAUL ec2api_listen_port "$EC2API_PORT"

commit_message:
Fix mistral dsvm gate

Because of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/235480/ path to
tempest conf now is defining in other way, need to export
special path and do not try to find tempest.conf using
relative path from test run directory.

Change-Id: I4de9d71332edab96e4d6c96f3b84f6ea2c459a67
(cherry picked from commit f8087961f611957c3e52239d8ecf064b922abf2c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/95/237895/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Path to directory with tempest.conf file, otherwise it will # take relative path from where the run tests command is being executed. export TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR=${TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR:-$TEMPEST_DIR/etc/} echo "Tempest configuration file directory: $TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR"

commit_message:
Change ports range in validators and test function

Current implementation for validating the port number and protocol
number accepts invalid values. For port number it accepts -1 which is
invalid, and the 0 which is used as programming technique for specifying
system-allocated (dynamic) ports. For protocol number it accepts only
one invalid value which is -1.

Proposed solution changes the range of:
- valid port numbers from <-1, 65535> to <1, 65535>
- valid protocol numbers from <-1, 255> to <0, 255>

Co-Authored-By: Wlodzimierz Borkowski <wlodek.borkowski@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kamil Rykowski <kamil.rykowski@intel.com>

Closes-Bug: 1329571
Closes-Bug: 1431367
Change-Id: I2dc83b611deaa0cc91d586dad1c01d8de91d1957

commit_message:
Add timeout for keystone client in proxy checker

Add 10 seconds timeout for Keystone client initialization
during HTTP proxy check, because otherwise it could hang
forever.
Also check that find_proxy returns IP address before
using it.

Change-Id: I4fabe0f5fee3d2acc3e7e2387ac858b2c56493c7
Closes-bug: #1499415

commit_message:
Using oslo-config-generator to instead of generate-config-file.sh

We don't need a separate script to wrap the oslo-config-generator. Like
other projects, we can just specify a config-generator config file to
define the namespaces.

Change-Id: Icc9b7b41baf89683c54f6aefcb3c4257f1e2f3d6

commit_message:
Add .eggs/ to .gitignore

setuptools uses an .eggs folder as a cache to avoid multiple
downloads.  git should ignore this directory as it will never
be added to the repo.

Change-Id: I49714b769ce42d45cf14c4c8f4c10ae40e638f4b

commit_message:
Remove unused common files

As part of the move from DocBook XML to RST, some files in the common
directory become orphaned since there's now no guide including them.

Remove all these orphaned files.

Change-Id: Ife5e0c791bd4e7cbfcd720d1acf56a067b3a5b06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/98/237898/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines:
VNC console proxy The VNC proxy is an OpenStack component that enables compute service users to access their instances through VNC clients. The web proxy console URLs do not support the websocket protocol scheme (ws://) on python versions less than 2.7.4. The VNC console connection works as follows: A user connects to the API and gets an access_url such as, http://ip:port/?token=xyz. The user pastes the URL in a browser or uses it as a client parameter. The browser or client connects to the proxy. The proxy talks to nova-consoleauth to authorize the token for the user, and maps the token to the private host and port of the VNC server for an instance. The compute host specifies the address that the proxy should use to connect through the nova.conf file option, . In this way, the VNC proxy works as a bridge between the public network and private host network. The proxy initiates the connection to VNC server and continues to proxy until the session ends. The proxy also tunnels the VNC protocol over WebSockets so that the noVNC client can talk to VNC servers. In general, the VNC proxy: Bridges between the public network where the clients live and the private network where VNC servers live. Mediates token authentication. Transparently deals with hypervisor-specific connection details to provide a uniform client experience.
About nova-consoleauth Both client proxies leverage a shared service to manage token authentication called nova-consoleauth. This service must be running for either proxy to work. Many proxies of either type can be run against a single nova-consoleauth service in a cluster configuration. Do not confuse the nova-consoleauth shared service with nova-console, which is a XenAPI-specific service that most recent VNC proxy architectures do not use.
Typical deployment A typical deployment has the following components: A nova-consoleauth process. Typically runs on the controller host. One or more nova-novncproxy services. Supports browser-based noVNC clients. For simple deployments, this service typically runs on the same machine as nova-api because it operates as a proxy between the public network and the private compute host network. One or more nova-xvpvncproxy services. Supports the special Java client discussed here. For simple deployments, this service typically runs on the same machine as nova-api because it acts as a proxy between the public network and the private compute host network. One or more compute hosts. These compute hosts must have correctly configured options, as follows.
VNC configuration options To customize the VNC console, use the following configuration options in your nova.conf file: To support live migration, you cannot specify a specific IP address for vncserver_listen, because that IP address does not exist on the destination host. The vncserver_proxyclient_address defaults to 127.0.0.1, which is the address of the compute host that Compute instructs proxies to use when connecting to instance servers. For all-in-one XenServer domU deployments, set this to 169.254.0.1. For multi-host XenServer domU deployments, set to a dom0 management IP on the same network as the proxies. For multi-host libvirt deployments, set to a host management IP on the same network as the proxies.
nova-novncproxy (noVNC) You must install the noVNC package, which contains the nova-novncproxy service. As root, run the following command: # apt-get install nova-novncproxy The service starts automatically on installation. To restart the service, run: # service nova-novncproxy restart The configuration option parameter should point to your nova.conf file, which includes the message queue server address and credentials. By default, nova-novncproxy binds on 0.0.0.0:6080. To connect the service to your Compute deployment, add the following configuration options to your nova.conf file: vncserver_listen=0.0.0.0 Specifies the address on which the VNC service should bind. Make sure it is assigned one of the compute node interfaces. This address is the one used by your domain file. <graphics type="vnc" autoport="yes" keymap="en-us" listen="0.0.0.0"/> To use live migration, use the 0.0.0.0 address. vncserver_proxyclient_address=127.0.0.1 The address of the compute host that Compute instructs proxies to use when connecting to instance vncservers.
Frequently asked questions about VNC access to virtual machines Q: What is the difference between nova-xvpvncproxy and nova-novncproxy? A: nova-xvpvncproxy, which ships with OpenStack Compute, is a proxy that supports a simple Java client. nova-novncproxy uses noVNC to provide VNC support through a web browser. Q: I want VNC support in the OpenStack dashboard. What services do I need? A: You need nova-novncproxy, nova-consoleauth, and correctly configured compute hosts. Q: When I use nova get-vnc-console or click on the VNC tab of the OpenStack dashboard, it hangs. Why? A: Make sure you are running nova-consoleauth (in addition to nova-novncproxy). The proxies rely on nova-consoleauth to validate tokens, and waits for a reply from them until a timeout is reached. Q: My VNC proxy worked fine during my all-in-one test, but now it doesn't work on multi host. Why? A: The default options work for an all-in-one install, but changes must be made on your compute hosts once you start to build a cluster. As an example, suppose you have two servers: PROXYSERVER (public_ip=172.24.1.1, management_ip=192.168.1.1) COMPUTESERVER (management_ip=192.168.1.2) Your nova-compute configuration file must set the following values: # These flags help construct a connection data structure vncserver_proxyclient_address=192.168.1.2 novncproxy_base_url=http://172.24.1.1:6080/vnc_auto.html xvpvncproxy_base_url=http://172.24.1.1:6081/console # This is the address where the underlying vncserver (not the proxy) # will listen for connections. vncserver_listen=192.168.1.2 novncproxy_base_url and xvpvncproxy_base_url use a public IP; this is the URL that is ultimately returned to clients, which generally do not have access to your private network. Your PROXYSERVER must be able to reach vncserver_proxyclient_address, because that is the address over which the VNC connection is proxied. Q: My noVNC does not work with recent versions of web browsers. Why? A: Make sure you have installed python-numpy, which is required to support a newer version of the WebSocket protocol (HyBi-07+). Q: How do I adjust the dimensions of the VNC window image in the OpenStack dashboard? A: These values are hard-coded in a Django HTML template. To alter them, edit the _detail_vnc.html template file. The location of this file varies based on Linux distribution. On Ubuntu 14.04, the file is at /usr/share/pyshared/horizon/dashboards/nova/instances/templates/instances/_detail_vnc.html. Modify the and options, as follows: <iframe src="{{ vnc_url }}" width="720" height="430"></iframe> Q: My noVNC connections failed with ValidationError: Origin header protocol does not match. Why? A: Make sure the base_url match your TLS setting. If you are using https console connections, make sure that the value of novncproxy_base_url is set explicitly where the nova-novncproxy service is running.

subject: Revert "DVR: Notify specific agent when update floatingip"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-19 12:44:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/7932f0c124c6ef7467542006c3510db567c6d262', 'message': 'Revert "DVR: Notify specific agent when update floatingip"

This reverts commit 52e91f48f2327b47f126893f9cb12f153380a9a6.

The patch broke notifications about FIP updates and triggered 100% gate
failures for Ironic gate.

I believe that I0cbe8c51c3714e6cbdc48ca37135b783f8014905 is also
breaking notifications, but for FIP create, which probably was not utilized in
any gate before and hence not caught in time.

I believe the author of the patch assumed that DVR mixin is not used for
legacy routers, while it is. And I wouldn't blame the author for such a
no-brainer assumption. The current L3/DVR code is such a mess that even
core reviewer team failed to catch the issue and merged it in.

The failure shows lots of issues with code quality, but also testing coverage.
Notifications to L3 agents should have been properly covered.

This does not answer the question why we get NotFound from database
on fetching a FIP router_id, but that's another issue that should be
investigated while Ironic gate is happy.

Change-Id: I4affac49d7c63f47c5654b94b28f4cb7471e87b0
Closes-Bug: #1507558
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-19 13:54:11.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py', 'neutron/tests/functional/services/l3_router/test_l3_dvr_router_plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a2f7e0343a147a30a637af4e1cb9a866f557e87d', 'message': 'Revert "DVR: Notify specific agent when update floatingip"

commit_message:
Revert "DVR: Notify specific agent when update floatingip"

This reverts commit 52e91f48f2327b47f126893f9cb12f153380a9a6.

The patch broke notifications about FIP updates and triggered 100%
gate failures for Ironic gate.

I believe that I0cbe8c51c3714e6cbdc48ca37135b783f8014905 is also
breaking notifications, but for FIP create, which probably was not
utilized in any gate before and hence not caught in time.

The change the reverted patch introduced made update_floatingip to
fetch router based on FIP router_id field on every call, which was
not the case before the patch. For some reason unknown at the
moment, we get NotFound from database on this fetch.

The patch does not answer the question why we get NotFound from
database on fetching a FIP router_id, but that's another issue that
should be investigated while Ironic gate is happy.

Change-Id: I4affac49d7c63f47c5654b94b28f4cb7471e87b0
Closes-Bug: #1507558
Related-Bug: #1507602

locate internal ports on different hosts self.core_plugin.update_port( self.context, int_port1['port']['id'], {'port': {'binding:host_id': 'host1'}}) self.core_plugin.update_port( self.context, int_port2['port']['id'], {'port': {'binding:host_id': 'host2'}}) # and create l3 agents on corresponding hosts helpers.register_l3_agent(host='host1', agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) helpers.register_l3_agent(host='host2', agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) # make net external ext_net_id = ext_subnet['subnet']['network_id'] self._update('networks', ext_net_id, {'network': {external_net.EXTERNAL: True}}) router1 = self._create_router(distributed=dvr) router2 = self._create_router(distributed=dvr) for router in (router1, router2): self.l3_plugin.update_router( self.context, router['id'], {'router': { 'external_gateway_info': {'network_id': ext_net_id}}}) self.l3_plugin.add_router_interface( self.context, router1['id'], {'subnet_id': int_subnet1['subnet']['id']}) self.l3_plugin.add_router_interface( self.context, router2['id'], {'subnet_id': int_subnet2['subnet']['id']}) floating_ip = {'floating_network_id': ext_net_id, 'router_id': router1['id'], 'port_id': int_port1['port']['id'], 'tenant_id': int_port1['port']['tenant_id']} floating_ip = self.l3_plugin.create_floatingip( self.context, {'floatingip': floating_ip}) with mock.patch.object( self.l3_plugin, '_l3_rpc_notifier') as l3_notif: updated_floating_ip = {'router_id': router2['id'], 'port_id': int_port2['port']['id']} self.l3_plugin.update_floatingip( self.context, floating_ip['id'], {'floatingip': updated_floating_ip}) if dvr: self.assertEqual( 2, l3_notif.routers_updated_on_host.call_count) expected_calls = [ mock.call(self.context, [router1['id']], 'host1'), mock.call(self.context, [router2['id']], 'host2')] l3_notif.routers_updated_on_host.assert_has_calls( expected_calls) self.assertFalse(l3_notif.routers_updated.called) else: self.assertEqual( 2, l3_notif.routers_updated.call_count) expected_calls = [ mock.call(self.context, [router1['id']], None), mock.call(self.context, [router2['id']], None)] l3_notif.routers_updated.assert_has_calls( expected_calls) self.assertFalse(l3_notif.routers_updated_on_host.called) def test_update_floating_ip_agent_notification(self): self._test_update_floating_ip_agent_notification() def test_update_floating_ip_agent_notification_non_dvr(self): self._test_update_floating_ip_agent_notification(dvr=False)

commit_message:
Replace github with openstack git repo

git.openstack.org is our official server, github is just a
read-only mirror.

Linking to github might also raise the expectation that we use the usual
github workflow which is not the case.

Change-Id: I3b3e8213c264757838c8e5fd33221eebf219cdc8

commit_message:
Don't download fedora-user as part of --all build

fedora-user is an optional image that is only used for testing the
deployed overcloud.  We shouldn't force everyone to download it as
part of the --all build when in many cases it won't be needed.  The
option to download it is left in the client though so it can still
be easily retrieved when necessary.

Change-Id: I3ea6ad911a6ee411f19379060da127ef0a6e75e3

commit_message:
Proposal for Flexible Resize Scheduling

Provides additional flexibility for specifying how destination hosts are
selected for resize operations.

blueprint flexible-resize-behavior

Change-Id: Ie231b0bc40b6842cb459be57b55e673650f25edd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/15/175115/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Provide Flexible Scheduling Decisions for Resize ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/flexible-resize-behavior The current resize behavior will generally involve migrating the VM; that is, the VM will be powered off, rebuilt with the new parameters on another host, powered on and the original deleted. While this works, there are situations in which an administrator just wants to leave a VM on the host it's already on (e.g., if the hypervisor supports a live resize operation as seen in Hyper-V or if the user doesn't doesn't want the VM to implicitly 'move' just for a resize operation). Problem description =================== This feature gives cloud administrators more control over the scheduling process with respect to resize operations. Right now it is quite possible that a resize operation will result in the VM changing host systems. While this might be acceptable in many situations, there are situations in which the administrator just wants the VM to stay put. There is an existing nova configuration option, allow_resize_to_same_host, but that only tells the scheduler that the VM's current host can be a candidate, but it by no means contractually agrees to that. This spec gives the operator that level of control. Use Cases ---------- * As a cloud administrator, I want to ensure that a resize operation does not move my VM, so that I can take advantage of hypervisors that can perform a resize operation while my VM is running (e.g., Hyper-V). Project Priority ----------------- This spec does not align with any of the major priorities. Proposed change =============== This change will introduce a new nova configuration option, which will be named resize_to_same_host; its acceptable values are: * force: force the VM to stay on its source host * forbid: forbid the VM from staying on its source host; this will be the default behavior to maintain backwards compatability * allow: allow (albeit not guarantee) the VM to stay on its source host This will allow us to deprecate the existing allow_resize_to_same_host option as it provides a superset of its functionality. In the release(s) in which these options co-exist (e.g., Liberty), allow_resize_to_same_host will take precedence over the new option. Alternatives ------------ There are a few alternatives: * We could pass additional details on the resize API itself versus using a configuration option. This wasn't selected because this level of granularity is likely overkill for what operators are trying to do. That is, this behavior is generally considered to be static and thus changing the API logic did not seem worthwhile. * We could do nothing and leave the function as is, but there have been requests for this functionality for several releases now, so it seems like something we should give the operators. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- The configuration options are documented in the prior sections. Operators that are not using the allow_resize_to_same_host feature would not have to do anything as this feature will be rolled out in a functionally equivalent manner prior to its introduction. For operators that are using the configuration option allow_resize_to_same_host configuration, they can set the new resize_to_same_host option to its respective counterpart since it provides a superset of behavior. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jwcroppe Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Nothing beyond unit tests should be needed for this. It can be trivially shown that the scheduler will select/exclude certain host(s) based on the presence or absence of the new configuration option. Documentation Impact ==================== The new nova configuration option will need to be documented as well as the deprecation of the allow_resize_to_same_host configuration option; we will target its removal in the M release. References ========== Related bug(s): * https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1323578 Related blueprint(s): * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/no-migration-resize Hypervisor support for active resize: * https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282286.aspx * http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_Logical_Partitioning History ======= None

commit_message:
Add whitespaces between words of tempest.conf

There is missing space in 'help' sectionf of couple
of options in conf.py, so tempest.conf comes out to
be joined words with no space in them.

Change-Id: I4aa707edf528d48f17335d1df83215e15f830e4b

and 'admin' so in tempest.conf it turns out to
be theadmin. Fix applied to config.py.

subject: Remove SUPPORTED_AGENT_TYPES for l2pop
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-19 13:17:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/678da7c639ca9682ad514b28e55764e73d81065e', 'message': 'Add OVSvApp Agent in SUPPORTED_AGENT_TYPES for l2pop

As part of networking-vsphere project which runs ovsvapp agent
on each ESXi host inside service VM, which talk to neutron-server
having l2pop enabled in a multi-hypervisor mode like KVM, ESXi.
The tunnels are not getting established between KVM compute node
and ESXi host. The l2pop mech_driver needs to embrace ovsvapp agent
to form the tunnels.

Hence, this patch-set addresses this issue.

Change-Id: I93ca5736e4aad41b851d2b7b082b4bb69d1632fb
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-19 13:19:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/58733c6ed85facaa3691d59a01a15ae39897918a', 'message': 'Add OVSvApp Agent in SUPPORTED_AGENT_TYPES for l2pop

As part of networking-vsphere project which runs ovsvapp agent
on each ESXi host inside service VM, which talk to neutron-server
having l2pop enabled in a multi-hypervisor mode like KVM, ESXi.
The tunnels are not getting established between KVM compute node
and ESXi host. The l2pop mech_driver needs to embrace ovsvapp agent
to form the tunnels.

Hence, this patch-set addresses the issue.

Change-Id: I93ca5736e4aad41b851d2b7b082b4bb69d1632fb
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-10-19 16:44:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f1cd9e00c5e77b6d0acd48b3a7368b3d28624457', 'message': 'Add OVSvApp Agent in SUPPORTED_AGENT_TYPES for l2pop

As part of networking-vsphere project which runs ovsvapp agent
on each ESXi host inside service VM, which talk to neutron-server
having l2pop enabled in a multi-hypervisor mode like KVM, ESXi.
The tunnels are not getting established between KVM compute node
and ESXi host. The l2pop mech_driver needs to embrace ovsvapp agent
to form the tunnels.

Hence, this patch-set addresses the issue.

commit_message:
Remove SUPPORTED_AGENT_TYPES for l2pop

In a world where agents can be out of tree,
this check seems no longer necessary.

As part of networking-vsphere project which runs ovsvapp agent
on each ESXi host inside service VM, which talk to neutron-server
having l2pop enabled in a multi-hypervisor mode like KVM, ESXi.
The tunnels are not getting established between KVM compute node
and ESXi host. The l2pop mech_driver needs to embrace ovsvapp agent
to form the tunnels.

Hence, this patch-set addresses the issue by removing the
SUPPORTED_AGENT_TYPES for l2pop.

Closes-Bug: #1507684
Change-Id: I93ca5736e4aad41b851d2b7b082b4bb69d1632fb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/70/236970/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: constants.AGENT_TYPE_OFA, constants.AGENT_TYPE_OVSVAPP]

subject: ovs: ovs agent updates the wrong port when using Xen + Neutron Problem: When VM is under HVM mode, ovs will create two ports and two interfaces for a single virtual ethernet interface inside the VM: One is named as tapx.0 which is qemu-emulated NIC, used when no PV drivers installed; The other one is named as vifx.0 which is the xen network frontend NIC, used when VM has PV drivers installed. Depending on the PV driver's existing, either of the two ports/interfaces will be used. But current implement can NOT process multiple ports/interfaces. If it configures(e.g. set tag) one interface but the other one is in fact used by ovs; it will have network problem.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-12 06:07:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e396fa1869359ecfe6eb3ecc0960072467fc6fe8', 'message': 'ovs: ovs agent updates the wrong port when using Xen + Neutron
Problem:
When VM is under HVM mode, ovs will create two ports and two interfaces for
a single virtual ethernet interface inside the VM: One is named as tapx.0
which is qemu-emulated NIC, used when no PV drivers installed; The other
one is named as vifx.0 which is the xen network frontend NIC, used when
VM has PV drivers installed. Depending on the PV driver's existing,
either of the two ports/interfaces will be used. But current implement
can NOT process multiple ports/interfaces. If it configures(e.g. set tag)
one interface but the other one is in fact used by ovs; it will have
network problem.

Solution:
 There are two potential solutions:
 1. configure both ports regardless which port will be used by ovs; so
 both have the same configuration.
 2. if there are multiple choices, ovs set the filed of "iface-status" as
active for the one taking effective; and others will be inactive. So the
other solution is to return the active one only. If there is any
switchover happens in later phase, the returned ofport should be changed
as the ofport is uniq for each port. Then treat this port as updated and
then it will configure the new chosen port accordingly.
 As the existing relative functions is implemented basing on the
assumption that only one single port/interface exists for each virtual
interface inside the VM. With the 1st solution, it requires much more
effort to change the existing data structure to hold multiple
ports/interfaces and corresponding it will make things more complicated.
So the 2nd solution has been chosen within this patch set.

Change-Id: I06e5e9123731e01e04c5f7f15ef857703521adc7
Closes-Bug: #1268955

commit_message:
ovs: ovs agent updates the wrong port when using Xen + Neutron
Problem:
When VM is under HVM mode, ovs will create two ports and two interfaces for
a single virtual ethernet interface inside the VM: One is named as tapx.0
which is qemu-emulated NIC, used when no PV drivers installed; The other
one is named as vifx.0 which is the xen network frontend NIC, used when
VM has PV drivers installed. Depending on the PV driver's existing,
either of the two ports/interfaces will be used. But current implement
can NOT process multiple ports/interfaces. If it configures(e.g. set tag)
one interface but the other one is in fact used by ovs; it will have
network problem.

Solution:
 There are two potential solutions:
 1. configure both ports regardless which port will be used by ovs; so
 both have the same configuration.
 2. if there are multiple choices, ovs set the filed of "iface-status" as
active for the one taking effective; and others will be inactive. So the
other solution is to return the active one only. If there is any
switchover happens in later phase, the returned ofport should be changed
as the ofport is uniq for each port. Then treat this port as updated and
then it will configure the new chosen port accordingly.
 As the existing relative functions is implemented basing on the
assumption that only one single port/interface exists for each virtual
interface inside the VM. With the 1st solution, it requires much more
effort to change the existing data structure to hold multiple
ports/interfaces and corresponding it will make things more complicated.
So the 2nd solution has been chosen within this patch set.

Change-Id: I06e5e9123731e01e04c5f7f15ef857703521adc7
Closes-Bug: #1268955
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/98/233498/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: by_id = {x['external_ids'].get('iface-id'): x for x in interface_info}

commit_message:
Consolidate module constants.

3 separate places had hardcoded values for the t-h-t directory. Many
values are/will be shared, this patch consolidates them to avoid having
them diverge in the future.

Depends-On: I98e19cc29d69cbd6636cd4ce77a07c7a0e3dc048
Change-Id: I205569f4be0bcee2b284048dec7ddf0b28bbd8a1

subject: Set --min-tmpfs for overcloud-full build
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-14 16:03:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/412701068739b0b9d6d31a1fb2338ae4d749edce', 'message': "Set --min-tmpfs for overcloud-full build

I consistently have problems building images on an 8 GB VM with
the undercloud already installed (which is the documented flow).
At 4 or 12 GB it works fine, but 8 seems to fall in a sweet spot
where the tmpfs usage of dib causes OOM problems.  4 GB works
because dib doesn't use tmpfs by default with that little memory,
and 12 GB seems to be sufficient to avoid running out of memory
even with tmpfs.

This changes passes the --min-tmpfs 5 parameter to the image build
for the overcloud-full image (the largest image by far) so it will
not attempt to build in tmpfs if there is less than 12 GB of RAM.
5 instead of 6 because due to rounding 6 would result in tmpfs not
being used on 12 GB VMs either (similar to how it is not used on a
4 GB VM even though the default is 2).

Note that tmpfs by default uses half of total memory, which is why
all of the min-tmpfs numbers are half of the expected memory on the
system.

"}]
commit_message:
Set --min-tmpfs for overcloud-full build

I consistently have problems building images on an 8 GB VM with
the undercloud already installed (which is the documented flow).
At 4 or 12 GB it works fine, but 8 seems to fall in a sweet spot
where the tmpfs usage of dib causes OOM problems.  4 GB works
because dib doesn't use tmpfs by default with that little memory,
and 12 GB seems to be sufficient to avoid running out of memory
even with tmpfs.

This changes passes the --min-tmpfs 5 parameter to the image build
for the overcloud-full image (the largest image by far) so it will
not attempt to build in tmpfs if there is less than 12 GB of RAM.
5 instead of 6 because due to rounding 6 would result in tmpfs not
being used on 12 GB VMs either (similar to how it is not used on a
4 GB VM even though the default is 2).

Note that tmpfs by default uses half of total memory, which is why
all of the min-tmpfs numbers are half of the expected memory on the
system.

Change-Id: I6254d04216936551e68ac02999f2bffc11b19f65
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/60/234860/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "%(dib_common_elements)s --min-tmpfs 5 2>&1 | "

commit_message:
Add HTTPS to image location help text

Glance supports http/https url, but the help text and description
only reference http.

Closes-Bug: #1495976

commit_message:
Install Guide Cleanup

This commit does the following:

- sets all shell prompts in code-blocks to the root prompt
- uses shell-session code-block since the shell prompt was being
  treated as a comment
- links configure-aodh.rst in configure.rst (running tox was
  complaining that this file wasn't being linked anywhere)
- other minor cleanup

Change-Id: I9e3ac8bb0cabd1cc17952cfd765dbb0d8f7b6fa2

commit_message:
Fix mistral dsvm gate

Because of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/235480/ path to
tempest conf now is defining in other way, need to export
special path and do not try to find tempest.conf using
relative path from test run directory.

Change-Id: I4de9d71332edab96e4d6c96f3b84f6ea2c459a67
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/96/235896/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Path to directory with tempest.conf file, otherwise it will # take relative path from where the run tests command is being executed. TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR=${TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR:-$TEMPEST_DIR/etc} echo "Tempest configuration file directory: $TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR"

commit_message:
Fix Debian install of Horizon in Debian

Adds a note about the new /horizon Alias in the Debian liberty package,
plus make sure the Finalize section is also present in Debian.

Change-Id: I572b417f7fa8e9f28fe878057da8962621c58550
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/36/234436/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: There are 2 modes of installation. One using /horizon as URL, keeping your default vhost (this is the default), and another setup which will remove the default Apache vhost and install Horizon on the webroot, which was the only available option before the Liberty release. If you prefer to do a manual setup and do not wish that Debian takes care of the Apache configuration, you can install the ``openstack-dashboard`` instead of ``openstack-dashboard-apache``. .. only:: ubuntu or debian

commit_message:
Make Ceph install from Source on RPM

Ceph doesnt install from source on RPM because Ceph pulls in
python-requests.  This causes a cpio error during unpacking
because requests is installed in the base image.  A simple
workaround is to remove in the nova-compute container which
is the only container this conflict occurs within.

backport: liberty

Change-Id: I493900854a53c98f1a5cb6478675a18feceefea5
Closes-Bug: #1508236
(cherry picked from commit 194bb93ff26cfda92ff79742d361350a353ecacd)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/72/237872/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: RUN pip uninstall -y requests \ && yum -y install \

commit_message:
Add option to generate sample conf file.

The README says you can generate it :
https://github.com/openstack/senlin/blob/master/etc/senlin/README-senlin.conf.txt
but this option was missing.
This patch allows user to use `tox -egenconfig` to directly
generate a sample conf file in etc/senlin/senlin.conf.sample.
This helps in vetting any doubts if the already given conf is
outdated or has incorrect config options.

Change-Id: I6f8aa4cd9fd7f5296997469f04a333d67e9ddbd5

Our tempest job has been passing, but OVN itself is going through some
*major* changes quite rapidly, and it's a bumpy ride adapting
networking-ovn to those changes.  We need to update networking-ovn to

and more.  It will be much easier if we can work through all of that in
several patches and then turn voting back on.

commit_message:
Revert "Make gate-tempest-dsvm-networking-ovn voting"

This patch reverts commit dea4c2cce33b6a6f0d18caca485be89e82ed51c0.

Our tempest job has been passing, but OVN itself is going through some
*major* changes quite rapidly, and it's a bumpy ride adapting
networking-ovn to those changes.  We need to update networking-ovn to
use OVN's new support for ACLs (security groups), distributed routing,
and more.  It will be much easier if we can work through all of that in
several patches and then turn voting back on.

Change-Id: If54532c79d1331f2154ed74697ce0e46fd652e91
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[Contributor Guide] RST section finished

1. Adds the following subsections:
   * Introduction to RST
   * Tables
   * Images
   * Profiling
   * Lists
   * Inline markups
   * Decorations
   * Commenting
2. Restructures the toc
3. Creates separate files for each subsection included in the
RST-related folder for simpler maintenance.

Change-Id: I08568fb37755109552edf9692b8f259660550a69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/66/232966/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============ Code samples ============ Format code snippets as standalone literal blocks. There are several ways to define a code-block within an RST file. Standard literal block ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Directive** | ``::`` or ``code`` | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Arguments** | none | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Options** | none | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Description** | * Introduces a standard reST literal block. | | | * Preserves line breaks and whitespaces. | | | * Automatically highlights language (Python, by | | | default) | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ Use ``::`` or ``code`` directive if you provide the code snippets written in one programming language within one file. By default, the code-block formatted this way is shown in a Python highlighting mode. To define another highlighting language, specify the ``highlight`` directive at the top of the file. Use the ``linenothreshold`` option with it to enumerate lines within the code-block. Always switch on the enumeration for the code-blocks that include more than 5 lines. **Input** .. code:: .. highlight:: console :linenothreshold: 5 This is the file body with the code snippet within: :: $ neutron ext-list -c alias -c name +-----------------+--------------------------+ | alias | name | +-----------------+--------------------------+ | agent_scheduler | Agent Schedulers | | binding | Port Binding | | quotas | Quota management support | | ... | ... | +-----------------+--------------------------+ Non-standard literal block ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Directive** | ``code-block`` | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Arguments** | ``python`` (default), ``ruby``, ``c``, ``console``, | | | ``ini``, and others | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Options** | ``linenos``, ``emphasize-lines`` | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | **Description** | * Specifies the highlighting language directly. | | | * Preserves line breaks and whitespaces. | | | * Has special options to number lines and emphasize | | | specific lines within the block. | +------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ To optimize the output of code for a specific programming language, specify the corresponding argument with ``code-block``. Use ``ini`` for configuration files, ``console`` for console inputs and outputs, and so on. Specify ``linenos`` for automatic enumeration of the code-blocks that include more than 5 lines. If you need to draw a user's attention to the particular code lines, use the ``emphasize-lines`` option followed by the numbers of the lines to emphasize. **Input** .. code:: .. code-block:: ini :emphasize-lines: 1, 4 # Configuration for nova-rootwrap # This file should be owned by (and only-writeable by) the root user [DEFAULT] # List of directories to load filter definitions from (separated by ',').

commit_message:
Increase Ceph RPM gpg key timeout to 90 seconds

The default timeout for Ceph GPG rpm key retrieval is 30 seconds.
In my testing, the GPG key takes approximately 50 seconds to download
often resulting in a failure to build containers that need to retrieve
the Ceph GPG sign key.  Crank up the timer to 90 seconds so the key
is more likely to be downloaded, allowing images to be built.

backport: liberty

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I7420cdf8d3b61aa9f4f52795fccbe5da3e48d57b
(cherry picked from commit a026ec253a616aa147cff72f43a38eda90789b0a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/00/237800/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make Ceph install from Source on RPM

Ceph doesnt install from source on RPM because Ceph pulls in
python-requests.  This causes a cpio error during unpacking
because requests is installed in the base image.  A simple
workaround is to remove in the nova-compute container which
is the only container this conflict occurs within.

backport: liberty

Change-Id: I493900854a53c98f1a5cb6478675a18feceefea5
Closes-Bug: #1508236

'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2015-10-02 16:45:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/75c58e4091cb2274046f472e35328da2170feb61', 'message': 'Split the FIP Namespace delete in L3 agent for DVR

Right now we are seeing a race condition in the l3 agent
for DVR routers when a floatingip is deleted and created.

The agent tries to delete the floatingip namespace and
while it tries to delete there is another call to add a
namespace. There is a timing windows in between these two
calls were sometimes the call to create a namespace succeeds
but, when tried to execute any commands in the namespace
it fails, since the namespace was deleted concurrently.

Since the fip namespace is associated with an external net
and each compute node has only one fip namespace, we would
like to only delete the fip namespace when the external net
is deleted.

The first step is to split the delete functionality into two.
The call to delete will only remove the dependency that
the fipnamespace has with the router namespace such as fpr and
rfp veth pairs.

The call to cleanup_fip_namespace will actually delete the
the fip namespace and the fg device.

Partial-Bug: #1501873
Change-Id: Ic94625d5a968f554af70c274b2b2c20ab64e2487

commit_message:
Split the FIP Namespace delete in L3 agent for DVR

Right now we are seeing a race condition in the l3 agent
for DVR routers when a floatingip is deleted and created.

The agent tries to delete the floatingip namespace and
while it tries to delete there is another call to add a
namespace. There is a timing window in between these two
calls where sometimes the call to create a namespace succeeds
but, when tried to execute any commands in the namespace
it fails, since the namespace was deleted concurrently.

Since the fip namespace is associated with an external net
and each node has only one fip namespace for an external net,
we would like to only delete the fip namespace when the
external net is deleted.

The first step is to split the delete functionality into two.
The call to fip_ns.cleanup will only remove the dependency that
the fipnamespace has with the router namespace such as fpr and
rfp veth pairs.

The call to fip_ns.delete will actually delete the
the fip namespace and the fg device.

Partial-Bug: #1501873
Change-Id: Ic94625d5a968f554af70c274b2b2c20ab64e2487
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/61/229561/26 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.debug('DVR: Do not destroy fip ns: %s', self.name)
deleted_lines: LOG.debug('DVR: destroy fip ns: %s', self.name) super(FipNamespace, self).delete()

commit_message:
Ensure we log exceptions on 500 responses

When running the api server under a real wsgi container the exceptions
aren't being propagated to the log file. This makes debugging a 500
error very difficult. This commit adds the option to the flask app
to ensure that we propagate tracebacks into the log.

Change-Id: Ibc4be9f98aaf3e6cb17ccaa39095ad52ebdada35
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/09/232809/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: app.config['PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS'] = True

commit_message:
Add parameter --tests-file to 'verify start'

With this parameter it is possible to load a list of tests from a file.

Closes-bug: #1450478

Change-Id: I576db470a7253151ed6753da4035a2f235278a39
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/87/230087/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @cliutils.args("--filename", dest="filename", type=str, required=False, help="Path to a file with a list of Tempest tests") filename=None, tempest_config=None, do_use=True, :param filename: Path to file with list of tests if filename and set_name: raise exceptions.InvalidArgumentsException("filename and set_name " "are not compatible") if filename and regex: raise exceptions.InvalidArgumentsException("filename and regex " "are not compatible") if not (regex or set_name or filename): if filename and not os.path.exists(filename): print("File '%s' with list of tests not found." % filename) return (1) filename, tempest_config,
deleted_lines: tempest_config=None, do_use=True, if not (regex or set_name): tempest_config,

commit_message:
Make webhook related DB query project safe

This patch makes webhook related DB queries project safe by default.
The load method of webhook module is also changed to add project_safe
parameter.

Change-Id: I071b2b741deee0d762f7bd0b121c17e6dce7f0fb
Implements: blueprint make-db-query-project-safe

commit_message:
Make event related DB queries project safe

This patch makes event related DB queries project safe by default.
load() method in event module is also changed to add project_safe
input parameter.

TODO:
 - Add test case for event module.

Implements: blueprint make-db-query-project-safe

commit_message:
Bump development version to 0.2.0

Bump development version to 0.2.0. When big tent proposal is accepted,

commit_message:
Add Bay to Magnum resources

This adds OS::Magnum::Bay to the Magnum resources

Change-Id: I238e84f50655250380d20cd6c0ea41f2a408bd55
Implements: partial blueprint magnum-resources
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/74/193174/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import six from heat.common import exception from heat.common.i18n import _ from heat.engine import clients from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import resource from heat.engine import support class Bay(resource.Resource): """ A resource for the Bay in Magnum. """ support_status = support.SupportStatus(version='2015.2') PROPERTIES = ( NAME, BAYMODEL, NODE_COUNT, DISCOVERY_URL, BAY_CREATE_TIMEOUT ) = ( 'name', 'baymodel', 'node_count', 'discovery_url', 'bay_create_timeout' ) properties_schema = { NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('The bay name.') ), BAYMODEL: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('The bay model.'), required=True ), NODE_COUNT: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.INTEGER, _('The node count for this bay.'), update_allowed=True ), DISCOVERY_URL: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Url used for bay node discovery') ), BAY_CREATE_TIMEOUT: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.INTEGER, _('Timeout for creating the bay in minutes. ' 'Set to 0 for no timeout.') ) } default_client_name = 'magnum' def handle_create(self): args = { 'name': self.properties.get(self.NAME), 'baymodel_id': self.properties.get(self.BAYMODEL), 'node_count': self.properties.get(self.NODE_COUNT), 'discovery_url': self.properties.get(self.DISCOVERY_URL), 'bay_create_timeout': self.properties.get(self.BAY_CREATE_TIMEOUT) } bay = self.client().bays.create(**args) self.resource_id_set(bay.uuid) return bay.uuid def check_create_complete(self, id): bay = self.client().bays.get(id) if bay.status != 'CREATE_COMPLETE': msg = (_("Bay '%(name)s' failed: %(code)s - %(reason)s") % {'name': self.name, 'code': 69, 'reason': "the reason"}) raise exception.Error(msg) return True def handle_update(self, json_snippet=None, tmpl_diff=None, prop_diff=None): if prop_diff: patch = [{'op': 'replace', 'path': '/' + k, 'value': v} for k, v in six.iteritems(prop_diff)] self.client().bays.update(self.resource_id, patch) def handle_delete(self): if not self.resource_id: return try: self.client().bays.delete(self.resource_id) except Exception as exc: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(exc) return self.resource_id def check_delete_complete(self, id): if not id: return True try: self.client().bays.get(id) except Exception as exc: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(exc) return True return False def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Magnum::Bay': Bay } def available_resource_mapping(): if not clients.has_client('magnum'): return {} return resource_mapping()

commit_message:
REST Amp Agent: Compare lower case MAC Addresses

When the post_plug_vip method is called on the rest amphora driver,
the agent on the amphora running the rest server attempts to find the
interface by the MAC address passed in through the API. On some OSes
the interfaces returned by the OS has the mac address in all lower case,
whereas the MAC address passed in through the API is in upper case.
Just lower() both and then compare.

Closes-Bug: #1507881
Change-Id: I4ddfd25911d31285513009432f80da080196e8b2

commit_message:
Change Identity API default version to 3

Devstack now issues all v3 OSC commands for our CI, and since v3
has everything v2 has, we should be able to switch to v3.

Furthermore, most OSC users were initially  using OSC since they
were looking to exploit v3 keystone capabilities.

Change-Id: If7de86946f6dd0f148aa5f526155cccf90adfcc3

added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. =============== Metadata search =============== A metadata search API should be included in Swift, but not included as a service itself. This specs describes a possible implementation that can be used to add a standard method for searching within object metadata. Problem Description =================== Currently there is no way to search within metadata of accounts, containers and objects - these are either stored in the account or container databases or in case of objects as extended file system attributes. This makes searching difficult, because one needs to send a HEAD request to every object which is inefficient and time-consuming. This spec describes a reference implementation to add metadata search to the existing API and makes use of external systems to execute the search itself. Proposed Change =============== This requires a new middleware inside the Swift proxy as well as a notification middleware that has been proposed as a separate spec. The metadata search itself should not be handled by Swift itself. Instead, Swift should include a API extension that makes it possible to search within metadata, and the search itself is executed in a different system. It needs to be discussed if the search operates on a container-level or even on an account-level; also if different search operators are supported, for example to search within metadata, or even search within object names. Alternatives ------------ This topic is not new, there have been some proposals in the past: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/MetadataSearch https://wiki.openstack.org/w/images/8/82/OSMS_API_v0.8_external.pdf https://wiki.openstack.org/w/images/a/ab/Object_Storage_Metadata_Search_Design_Session_v4.pdf Implementation ============== The idea for a possible implementation and workflow is like this: 1. A user uploads a new or modified objects or updates the metadata using a POST request. 2. A notification is sent out to an external metadata search engine using a message queue to update the stored metadata. 3. A new API endpoint, for example a querystring operator has been added to Swift 4. A user wants to search for cat pictures in all description metadata keys and sends a GET request like "/v1/AUTH_accountname/containername?metadata=description:cats" to the Swift proxy 5. The Swift proxy forwards the query to the external metadata search system and returns a list of found objects to the user. The last step is similar to what is already included in Swift: a GET request on a container returns a listing of objects. There are some existing querystrings to limit the returned results, like filtering on a prefix. In this special case the result set will be limited to objects whose metadata matches the given querystring. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: cschwede Work Items ---------- Develop proxy middleware Repositories ------------ None Servers ------- None DNS Entries ----------- None Documentation ------------- Extended documentation needs to be written: - administrator guide how to configure this to use an external service - user guide giving examples how to use this feature Security -------- Metadata search has to ensure that only object names are returned that are stored within the same account and/or container. ACLs need to validated as well, for example a user that has only write permission should not be abled to retrieve any metadata at all. Testing ------- Functional as well as unit tests for the new middleware have to be included. Tests will either need a working third-party metadata search or a dummy implementation (preferred). Dependencies ============ - Notification spec

commit_message:
Properly handle segmentation_id in OVS agent

The segmentation_id of a OVS VLAN can be None, but a recent change
assumed that it was always an integer. It highlighted the fact that we
try to store None in the OVS database, which got stored as a string.
This fixes the storage, and handles loading the value while keeping
compatibility.

Change-Id: I6e7df1406c90ddde254467bb87ff1507a4caaadd
Closes-Bug: #1494281

commit_message:
Prevent false negative results during wait for resource deletion

This patch replaces get_status for latest_status to None value
to prevent 404 NotFound exception, if resource removed faster, than
wait code will interpreted.
Change-Id: I4f3baaf01e14d4794ce675ad37b300b876b9fc12
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/24/234124/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If resource deleted before this code block start executing # rally will catch a NotFound exception try: latest_status = get_status(resource, status_attr) latest_status_update = start except exceptions.GetResourceNotFound: if check_deletion: return else: raise

commit_message:
Support private address override in inventory

ansible inventory supports a command line switch --private which
overrides the clouds.yaml setting. Support passing it in.

Change-Id: I74bf98be26b605a5e9ac74ab478f421c39616d74

commit_message:
Revert "Match on dsvm-fedora-22 and dsvm-f21 nodes"

This reverts commit 29a714741b24c1247dfaf9fd2863fce3d8438602.

There is only one fedora node type, "fedora-22".  I think the
NOT_REGISTERED errors from the puppet jobs might have been related to
a zuul reload around the same time.

Change-Id: Ie8d6b9d1f9840627ada0e18d4a725b475be6d3ce

subject: WIP: Enable Role-based access control using oslo.policy in Swift
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-26 06:15:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/b24f753cc3a1c0f7afa754760db511db0bfb713d', 'message': "Enable Role-based access control using oslo.policy in Swift

This patch realizes Role-based access control (RBAC) with Keystone
using oslo.policy library in Swift.

All keystoneauth authorisations logic were translated into json
policy format, to ensure backward compatibly.

The oslo.policy library was in oslo-incubator but this library
will be graduated in Kilo-2 milestones (Feb. 5).
Until the milestones the current entry for the library in
'test-requirement.txt' should be temporary one.
https://github.com/openstack/oslo-specs/blob/master/specs/kilo/graduate-policy.r

How does it work:
* Either 'reseller_admin_role' or 'operator_roles' is specified
  in proxy-server.conf, RBAC works with the parameters.
* Neither 'reseller_admin_role' nor 'operator_roles' is not specified
  in proxy-server.conf and 'policy_file' is specided the configuration
  file,  RBAC works with specified policy file.
* When the default policy file (default_policy.json) is used, both
  behavior should be same.

Change-Id: Ia55b81cc14c9bf917c402e5a00c08365e4d340b1
Implements: blueprint updated-authorization-policy

using oslo.policy library in Swift.

All keystoneauth authorisations logic were translated into json

'test-requirement.txt' should be temporary one.

How does it work:
* Either 'reseller_admin_role' or 'operator_roles' is specified
  in proxy-server.conf, RBAC works with the parameters.
* Neither 'reseller_admin_role' nor 'operator_roles' is not specified
  in proxy-server.conf and 'policy_file' is specided the configuration
  file,  RBAC works with specified policy file.
* When the default policy file (default_policy.json) is used, both
  behavior should be same.

Change-Id: Ia55b81cc14c9bf917c402e5a00c08365e4d340b1
Implements: blueprint updated-authorization-policy

This patch realizes Role-based access control (RBAC) with Keystone
using oslo.policy library in Swift.

All keystoneauth authorisations logic were translated into json
policy format, to ensure backward compatibly.

Note that deployers need to specify a policy file which is created by
themselves. There are two default policy files which are stored in
/etc/swift. One of the policy files can be a base of their cluster.
* the cluster is configured with composite tokens which is
  realized in #137086, the policy-service.json file will be used.
* the cluster is configured without composite tokens which is
  realized in #137086, the policy.json file will be used.

How does it work:
* keystoneauth works with a policy file which is specified in
  proxy-server.conf as policy_file.
* If 'reseller_admin_role', 'operator_roles' and 'service_roles' are
  specified in proxy-server.conf, keystoneauth updates the policy
  with the information and works with it.

Notes (reasons for WIP):
* oslo.policy seems to be not supported HTTP_X_SERVICE_ROLES so
  I created ServiceRoleCheck class but it is better to have it
  in the library. I will get in touch with oslo.policy guys about
  it.
* Didn't do func test with keystone yet.
* ...
