commit_message:
Swift-Storlets - allowing dynamic compute functions

A new middleware for Openstack Swift allowing to dynamically add
compute functions along the pipeline, without the need to epxlicitly
add new middleware.

Code reference can be found here:
    https://github.com/Open-I-Beam/swift-storlets

Change-Id: I273d23db6e9373a71115e4b685cc1dfe9536f063
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift-specs refs/changes/37/164537/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============== Swift Storlets ============== WIP Revision History: * 03/14: Initial Revision 1. Introduction and Problem description ======================================= While OpenStack Swift is an advanced object storage solution, it misses capabilities to perform light weight computation tasks that may be required by customers. Users who keep their data in Swift and wish to execute various tasks on the data, need to download the data from Swift, perform the tasks and upload the modified data back to the cluster. We mention a couple of examples: * CSV files filtering as part of the GET data path. * Metadata extraction as part of the GET data path (e.g. EXIF metadata from images, PDF document metadata) * Metadata enrichment as part of the PUT data path (e.g. save EXIF metadata as Swift user metadata) One way to add such tasks is through WSGI middleware. Doing so, however, requires to alter the pipeline, an action which involves an admin and requires a restart. Additional limitations to extending the Swift functionality via middleware plugins are: * A middleware bug can cause data loss or corruption as it runs with the 'swift' user privileges. * The same pipeline is applicable to all requests (even if not all plugins get activated for each and every request) * Middleware must be written in python. * Each new functionality requires a new middleware. To improve on this we introduce Swift Storlets, a Swift centric solution that will extend Swift with the ability to dynamically add computational capabilities. At a high level, Swift Storlets allow users to write their code, package it and then deploy it as data objects to Swift. Once deployed the code can be explicitly invoked as if it was part of the pipeline. The invocation itself is done in an isolated manner where the data accessible by the computation is only the object's data. Moreover, the computation is isolated and has no access to disks, network or to the Swift request environment. We mention that this approach is aligned with recent trends that integrate between storage and computation by performing certain computational tasks close to the data, thus avoiding unnecessary data movements over the network. While these trends are well established in the analytics world, we only start to see them in object stores, e.g. `ZeorVM <http://www.zerovm.org/>`_ and `Joyent/Manta <https://www.joyent.com/object-storage>`_ 2. High Level Architecture ========================== Swift Storlets contain two major modules: The Swift Storlets middleware and the Swift Storlets compute engine (which is external to Swift). The Swift Storlets middleware is responsible to communicate with the compute engine passing it the data to be processed and getting back the result. The compute engine is responsible for sandboxing the execution of the extended functionality. We use the term Storlet to refer to the binary code implementing the extended functionality. Thinking of the Swift Storlet middleware as a way to dynamically extend the pipeline suggests that it can be used for all Swift services (proxy, account, container and object). At this point, however, we suggest adding the middleware to the proxy and object services only, focusing on the object PUT and GET flows. We believe that this is a simple yet non-trivial starting point that brings real value. The Storlet compute engine is beyond the scope of this spec, and we have opened a reference implementation of a compute engine that is based on Docker. The reference implementation can be found here (TODO) 2.1 Storlet ----------- A Storlet is the binary code that implements the functionality one wishes to add and invoke in a dynamic way. The operation of deploying a Storlet is uploading it to Swift as a regular object to a designated container. We note that this puts the Storlets in a scope of a Swift account. 2.2 Swift Storlet Middleware ---------------------------- The Storlet middleware is responsible to handle the logic of storlet activation with the compute engine. When a storlet is executed the middleware extracts the data stream from the request and routes it to the engine. The middleware then gets back the result and wraps it in an iterator that the Swift WSGI framework can work with. Focusing on object's GET and PUT flows the middleware is added to the proxy and object services pipeline. 2.3 Swift Storlets Compute Engine --------------------------------- The compute engine is responsible for running the Storlet in an isolated and secured way. Although the compute engine is beyond the scope of this spec, we do believe that it should not span Swift accounts, that is, the same sandbox instance will not serve requests coming from different accounts. This means that if, e.g. the compute engine is Docker based then the same Docker container will not be used for serving requests from different accounts. A compute engine instance would run on the same node as the Storlets middleware where the request is being processed. 2.4 The Middleware and Compute Engine Interface ----------------------------------------------- The interface between the middleware and the compute engine manifests in a python object that is created in the running context of the Swift Storlet middleware and is used for interfacing the compute engine. As such the API will be defined by an 'abstract base class'. We call that class StorletGateway. Other than a reference implementation of that class that works with our Docker based compute engine, part of the upstream contribution is a stub implementation that allows to run tests. 2.5 Bringing it all together ---------------------------- In this section we illustrate the end-to-end scenario at a high level. #. A user writes a Storlet. In our reference implementation this involves writing a standard Java code that implements our reference's Storlets interface. #. The code is then packaged in a single file that can be uploaded to Swift as a single object. Again, in our reference implementation the code is packaged as a jar file. #. The packaged code is uploaded to Swift into a designated container (whose name is configurable), together with some mandatory metadata described later. #. The Storlet middleware validates the metadata and continues the regular Swift PUT flow. #. The user can now invoke a Storlet via GET or PUT on a specific object by specifying a designated header. The header contains the name of the Storlet to invoke over the object appearing in the request URI. #. The request is being picked up by the Storlet middleware. For GET of regular objects it will be picked in the storage node, for PUT or GET of an SLO it will be picked in the proxy node. #. The Storlet middleware checks that the Storlet is already registered with the compute engine. If not it brings a copy of the Storlet from the designated container where it was uploaded. The middleware can now invoke the storlet 3. Goals ======== This spec describes the Swift Storlet middleware that is focused on the GET and PUT flows of objects. The spec defines the following APIs: #. The Swift API extensions that allow to invoke Storlets during GET or PUT of an object. #. The StorletGateway API. #. API for Storlets metadata validation on upload of new Storlets. 4. Future Goals =============== Add the ability to perform compute on an existing object, where the output of the computation is another object (or objects). One way to do so is to leverage the copy flow, so as to have a copy with X-Run-Storlet which is essentially a copy-modify. 5. Proposed Change to Swift =========================== The spec is about adding a new middleware to Swift that does not require any change to the Swift code. Also, there are no modification to the existing Swift API. The usage of Storlets is done using newly suggested HTTP headers. Part of the suggested addition is a stub implementation of the compute engine part that will allow to run tests. 5.1 Swift Configuration ----------------------- The Storlet middleware should be configured on the proxy and storage nodes and it should be placed before the SLO middleware, for example: :: pipeline = catch_errors gatekeeper healthcheck proxy-logging cache bulk tempurl ... storlet_handler ... slo proxy-logging proxy-server The Storlet middleware needs to be configured as follows: :: [filter:storlet_handler] use = egg:storlets#storlet_handler storlet_container = storlet storlet_dependency = dependency storlet_logcontainer = storletlog storlet_timeout = 40 ( Timeout ) storlet_additional_conf = /etc/swift/storlets-docker.conf Where: #. storlet_container reflects the Swift container name where Storlets should be uploaded to. #. storlet_dependency reflects the Swift container name where Storlets dependencies should be uploaded to. Dependencies are e.g. additional jars the Storlet code is dependent upon. #. storlet_logcontainer reflects the Swift container name where storlets execution logs are uploaded to. TBD. #. storlet_timeout reflects the time the Storlet middleware allows for the storlet to e.g. start streaming back the response. #. storlet_additional_conf points to whatever additional configuration is required for the compute engine implementation. 5.2 Storlet Deployment ---------------------- To deploy a new Storlet in Swift the user needs to upload the Storlet binary object to the designated Swift container (as configured by storlet_container). The name of the Storlet needs to be of the following format: storlet name.verion The upload must include the following metadata: :: 'X-Object-Meta-Storlet-Language':'Java' 'X-Object-Meta-Storlet-Interface-Version':'1.0', 'X-Object-Meta-Storlet-Dependency': '' 'X-Object-Meta-Storlet-ID: storlet main invocation class' 'X-Object-Meta-Storlet-Key1' 'X-Object-Meta-Storlet-Key2' Where: #. The storlet language permits to support more than one language binding in the compute engine. #. The interface version identifies the interface that the Storlet supports. This allows backward compatibility with older Storlets. #. The dependencies is a list of software dependencies (if any), e.g. a set of Jars the Storlet is dependent on. #. The Storlet id is a way to uniquely identify the Storlet. In our reference implementation this is the fully qualified java class name of the class implementing the Storlet. #. The keys define the request environment variables we wish to pass to the Storlet, e.g. X-Meta-Object-'*'. These instruct the middleware what request env fields to pass the Storlet. Our current implementation passes all user defined metadata fields. All storlet related metadata will be stored as part of object system metadata. 5.3 Invocation API Extensions ----------------------------- This spec focuses on invocation on either GET or PUT of an object. To invoke a Storlet one needs to add the header :: 'X-Run-Storlet' : 'storlet name.version'. This name must be identical to the object name as uploaded to Swift during deployment time. 5.4 The StorletGateway API -------------------------- Here is a very initial suggestion for that API, which our reference implementation use. We leave most of the details out so that this can be better formed by the community. :: StorletsGateway(account, conf) StorletResponse invoke_get(StoreltGetRequest) StorletResponse invoke_put(StoreltPutRequest) Few notes: #. The init takes as input the account context of the class. #. Deploying a Storlet is left as an implementation detail: Recall that deploying a Storlet is done by uploading it to a designated container. The above API does not specify any such method, hence it is left as an implementation detail. #. In our reference implementation: #. StorletResponse contains two fields representing an output object: #. A file descriptor from which the Storlet output data can be read, and #. a dictionary holding the output metadata #. Similarly, StorletGetRequest and StorletPUTRequest contain two equivalent fields representing an input object. 5.5 SLO / DLO ------------- There are no issues with SLO, since the Storlet middleware may be placed before the SLO middleware and thus support GET requests as is. For PUT requests, the Storlet may be applied on the chunks as they arrive in Swift. 5.6 Ranges ---------- There are two ways to interpret a GET request with ranges and X-Run-Storlet: #. The ranges specify which bits need to get into the Storlet #. The ranges specify which parts of the Storlet output the user wishes to get back Out reference implementation includes the first interpratation. We leave for discussion the need for the second. 5.7 EC, Encryption ------------------ The question with EC and encryption is how do we run a Storlet over an encoded or an encrypted object. A naive solution for that problem is using the internal client as done with container sync. 5.8 ETAG -------- For the PUT flow since a Storlet may modify an object on write, we follow the same approach used in EC / Encryption regarding the user's ETAG validation. For the GET flow we stress that since the returned entity of a GET with X-Run-Storlet is not something that is persistent in the object store there is no issue with returning without an ETAG. 5.9 HEAD on object, container listing, container sizes, etc ----------------------------------------------------------- We note that doing a HEAD on an object may return different results than doing a GET on the same object with X-Run-Storlet. We believe that this is not really a problem from the same reason mentioned in the ETAG section. 5.10 High Level Flow -------------------- In this section we describe at a high level the GET and PUT flow with X-Run-Storlet. 5.10.1 GET ~~~~~~~~~~ Running the computation during GET means that the initiator of the request does not get the object's data or metadata as they are kept in Swift but rather the result of the computation over the data and metadata. The GET flow described below is for objects that are not SLO and are not in a container that is part of an EC policy. #. A GET request with X-Run-Storlet hits the proxy server. #. The proxy server routes the request to an object server holding a replica of the desired object. #. The Storlets object middleware intercepts the response coming back from the object server app. #. The middleware extracts from the response #. The metadata #. The app_iter file descriptor #. The middleware wraps the metadata and file descriptor in a StorletGETRequest object and calls the StorletGatway invoke_get API call. #. The StorletResponse from the invoke_get API call consists of the returned metadata and output file descriptor. The metadata is translated to Swift response headers, and the file descriptor is wrapped in an iterator that is returned as the Swift response app_iter field. 5.10.2 PUT ~~~~~~~~~~ Running the computation during PUT means that the object created in Swift will consist of the data and metadata as output by the computation rather than the uploaded data and metadata. #. A PUT request with X-Run-Storlet hits the proxy server. #. The Storlet middleware intercepts the request and extracts #. The metadata headers #. The WSGI input object iterator #. The middleware wraps the metadata and iterator in a StorletPUTRequest object and calls the StorletGatway invoke_put API call. #. The StorletResponse from the invoke_put API call consists of returned metadata and output file descriptor. The metadata is merged with the original request headers, and the file descriptor is wrapped with an iterator placed in the original request env 'wsgi.input' field. The modified request is the one that will continue traverse the pipeline.

commit_message:
Additional exit codes for swift-drive-audit

Encode the swift-drive-audit result and the actions performed in the exit
status, in particular if a drive was unmounted or was not available.

Closes-Bug: #1359664
Change-Id: Id230082dd59e935aa81f10e98852b89d914a17de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/98/124398/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Upon exit, the following will be bitwise OR-ed: # EX_OK: no errors found in log files # 2: a device was unmounted # 4: a device was unavailable while unmounting EX_DEV_UNMOUNTED = 2 EX_DEV_UNAVAILABLE = 4 sys.exit(os.EX_OSFILE) sys.exit(os.EX_USAGE) sys.exit(os.EX_CONFIG) logger.error('Error: unable to compile regex pattern "%s"' % error_pattern) sys.exit(os.EX_DATAERR) exitcode = os.EX_OK if not device: exitcode = exitcode | EX_DEV_UNAVAILABLE logger.info("Errors found but device unavailable: %s:%s" % (kernel_device, count)) continue mount_point = device[0]['mount_point'] if mount_point.startswith(device_dir): logger.info("Unmounting %s with %d errors" % (mount_point, count)) subprocess.call(['umount', '-fl', mount_point]) logger.info("Commenting out %s from /etc/fstab" % (mount_point)) comment_fstab(mount_point) unmounts += 1 exitcode = exitcode | EX_DEV_UNMOUNTED sys.exit(exitcode)
deleted_lines: sys.exit(1) sys.exit(1) sys.exit(1) sys.exit('Error: unable to compile regex pattern "%s"' % error_pattern) if device: mount_point = device[0]['mount_point'] if mount_point.startswith(device_dir): logger.info("Unmounting %s with %d errors" % (mount_point, count)) subprocess.call(['umount', '-fl', mount_point]) logger.info("Commenting out %s from /etc/fstab" % (mount_point)) comment_fstab(mount_point) unmounts += 1

subject: Support of the Linux socket option SO_REUSEPORT
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-27 15:03:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/191e58a47b4c81891b96e73c80e7dadf7ec24352', 'message': 'Support of the Linux socket option SO_REUSEPORT

Linux, since version 3.9, added a new option for TCP and UDP sockets:
SO_REUSEPORT. Multiple processes can bind to the same port if they
each set the SO_REUSEPORT option.

This feature have two usages. It loadbalances the traffic over
multiple processes, usefull when the server is not multithreaded. It
also helps to provide a zero-downtime restart. Zero-downtime restart
is the main objective of that patch.

The new configuration option DEFAULT/reuseport, available for
account|container|object|proxy server, enables the socket option if
the kernel is a Linux>=3.9. It is disabled by default.

The new runtime options --finish=<pid> and --terminate=<pid> send,
respectively, the signals SIGHUP and SIGTERM to the pid specified.

To execute a zero-downtime restart, a new server must be started with
the --finish=$PID option, where $PID is the pid of the currently
running process.

Example, for a proxy server:
    /usr/bin/python /usr/bin/swift-proxy-server \
        /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf \
        --finish $(cat /var/run/swift/proxy-server.pid)

commit_message:
Support of the Linux socket option SO_REUSEPORT

To reload servers processes, the current behavior is to send a HUP to the
process that will (gently) terminate the server. Then, another server must be
started. It means that during that short interval, no processes are listening
for incoming requests.

Linux, since version 3.9, added a new option for TCP and UDP sockets:
SO_REUSEPORT. Multiple processes can bind to the same port if they
each set the SO_REUSEPORT option.

This feature have two usages. It loadbalances the traffic over
multiple processes, useful when the server is not multithreaded. It
also helps to provide a zero-downtime restart by allowing that, at any time,
there is always at least one process listening for incoming requests.
Zero-downtime restart is the main objective of that patch.

The new behavior is to enable the socket option, when available, for
account|container|object|proxy server. The option is considered available when
the underlying OS is Linux>=3.9.

The new runtime options --finish=<pid> and --terminate=<pid> send,
respectively, the signals SIGHUP and SIGTERM to the pid specified.

To execute a zero-downtime restart, a new server must be started with
the --finish=$PID option, where $PID is the pid of the currently
running process.

Example, for a proxy server:
    /usr/bin/python /usr/bin/swift-proxy-server \
        /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf \
        --finish $(cat /var/run/swift/proxy-server.pid)

The swift-init command is modified to use these options when appropriate.

Change-Id: I3a6cd3635545402203fa8c5de0c43ede81fb7c0e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/59/137659/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: object-replicator warns when object dirs mismatch with policy settings
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-11 11:51:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/277e8bff3b25079a3c6633d978a08e2bd92ac4f9', 'message': "object-replicator warns when object dirs mismatch with policy settings

Currently, object-replicator runs only for 'objects-<policy_idx>'
directories whose 'idx' is defined in swift.conf. This means that, for
example, if there are 'objects', 'objects-1' and 'objects-2' directories
in some devices but swift.conf only contains [storage-policy:0] and
[storage-policy:1] sections, object-replicator does not seek 'objects-2'
directory.

However, operators cannot be noticed that replicator does not work for
'objects-2' dir because there is no log output. Therefore, this can cause
delay in detecting config mismatches among swift servers or other
unexpected situations and then, in the worst case, this can cause data
losses.

This patch enables to output logs in the case of the mismatch between
object directory infomation and swift.conf. This mismatch check process
is executed after the completion of replication processes because the
sooner a replicator process starts the better.

Change-Id: Ie005775a626f12b0d0fb339533e63918978a89f2

commit_message:
object-replicator warns when object dirs mismatch with policy settings

Currently, object-replicator runs only for 'objects-<policy_idx>'
directories whose 'idx' is defined in swift.conf. This means that, for
example, if there are 'objects', 'objects-1' and 'objects-2' directories
in some devices but swift.conf only contains [storage-policy:0] and
[storage-policy:1] sections, object-replicator does not seek 'objects-2'
directory.

However, operators cannot be noticed that replicator does not work for
'objects-2' dir because there is no log output. Therefore, this can cause
delay in detecting config mismatches among swift servers or other
unexpected situations and then, in the worst case, this can cause data
losses.

This patch enables to output logs in the case of the mismatch between
object directory infomation and swift.conf. This mismatch check process
is executed after the completion of replication processes because the
sooner a replicator process starts the better.

Change-Id: Ie005775a626f12b0d0fb339533e63918978a89f2
Related-Bug: 1375438
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/89/163389/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_replicator_with_unconfigured_policy(self): objects_999 = os.path.join( self.devices, 'sda', diskfile.get_data_dir(999, conf_check=False)) os.mkdir(objects_999) # Run a replicate method without object-999 ring self.replicator.replicate() # Check if an appropriate log is shown self.assertEquals(self.replicator.logger.log_dict['warning'][0][0][0], 'Skipped %s because policy index %s is not defined ' 'in the conf file' % (objects_999, 999))

subject: Sync local regions first, and always shuffle nodes

commit_message:
Sync local regions first, and always shuffle nodes

Move the recently added shuffle nodes call from ObjectReplicator.update under
the common collect_jobs method so it also benifits update and update_deleted.

When primary locations span more than two regions, attempt to sync
cross-region in a deterministic fashion so that efficent replication has the
best chance of an even distribution of WAN traffic (region 0 will push to 1
which will push to 2, then region 0 can delete its handoff).

N.B. the use of region id is only to ensure deterministic ordering, and not
ment to convey any knowledge of region locality, but it theoretically could be
made configurable to handle affinity awareness.

Change-Id: I4b05d2efd647cead4e96d0aca5d89aaf3792aa21
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/41/159241/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestReplicatorHelpers(unittest.TestCase): def test_shuffle_nodes_removes_primary_local_dev(self): nodes = [ dict(id=0, region=0), dict(id=1, region=0), dict(id=2, region=0), ] for node in nodes: local_dev = node shuffled_nodes = object_replicator.shuffle_nodes(local_dev, nodes) self.assertFalse(local_dev in shuffled_nodes) self.assertEqual(2, len(shuffled_nodes)) def test_shuffle_nodes_orders_by_region(self): nodes = [ dict(id=0, region=0), dict(id=1, region=1), dict(id=2, region=2), ] expected = { 0: (1, 2), 1: (2, 0), 2: (0, 1), } for node in nodes: local_dev = node shuffled_nodes = object_replicator.shuffle_nodes(local_dev, nodes) self.assertEqual(expected[local_dev['id']], tuple(n['region'] for n in shuffled_nodes)) def test_shuffle_nodes_handoff_orders_by_region(self): nodes = [ dict(id=0, region=0), dict(id=1, region=2), dict(id=2, region=4), ] expected = { 6: (0, 2, 4), 1: (2, 4, 0), 3: (4, 0, 2), } for local_region, expected_order in expected.items(): local_dev = dict(id=3, region=local_region) shuffled_nodes = object_replicator.shuffle_nodes(local_dev, nodes) self.assertEqual(expected_order, tuple(n['region'] for n in shuffled_nodes)) def test_shuffle_nodes_local_first(self): nodes = [ dict(id=0, region=0), dict(id=1, region=0), dict(id=2, region=1), ] local_dev = nodes[0] shuffled_nodes = object_replicator.shuffle_nodes(local_dev, nodes) self.assertEqual(2, len(shuffled_nodes)) self.assertEqual(shuffled_nodes[0]['region'], local_dev['region']) self.assertNotEqual(shuffled_nodes[1]['region'], local_dev['region']) def test_shuffle_nodes_calls_shuffle_for_remote_region_nodes(self): nodes = [ dict(id=0, region=0), dict(id=1, region=1), dict(id=2, region=1), ] local_dev = nodes[0] with mock.patch('swift.obj.replicator.random') as mock_random: object_replicator.shuffle_nodes(local_dev, nodes) subject: Cleanup object-replicator handoff/rebalance partition syncing
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-25 00:18:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/3afe58174ff7ae0af3b555482a74cbc802bbd316', 'message': "Cleanup object-replicator handoff/rebalance partition syncing

When removing a partition because of handoff or in response to a
rebalance, remove synced suffixes (and objects) based on the work
performed instead of with rmtree to minimize the impact of a long race
window while syncing the partition to the remote nodes (between the time
when jobs are collected, and the partition is removed).

Since a node which is no longer a primary location does not expect to
receive many updates to the part after a rebalance, this change mainly
effects handoff reversion.  When an object server is accepting writes as
a handoff it's replicator daemon is also trying to remove the partition
from the node after syncing it to the primaries.  If it receives a write
for a new suffix while syncing it will not remove the partition.  If it
is using ssync and receives a write for a different object (hash) while
syncing it will not remove the partition, but an update to a
successfully synced object may still be subject to a race
(clean_suffixes goes object by object, but still uses rmtree without
respect the synced timestamps).

After syncing and removing all suffixes in the partition, the
object-replicator will wait until the subsequent pass to remove the
hashes.pkl, the .lock file, and the otherwise empty partition dir with
rmtree.

Also cleanup the ssync interface for remote check jobs during efficient
cross region replication.

Closes bug #1408061

Change-Id: I40d107c567f02e219f04b1a74d7060f5280432d5

commit_message:
Cleanup object-replicator handoff/rebalance partition syncing

When removing a partition because of handoff or in response to a
rebalance, remove synced suffixes (and objects) based on the work
performed instead of with rmtree to minimize the impact of a long race
window while syncing the partition to the remote nodes (between the time
when jobs are collected, and the partition is removed).

Since a node which is no longer a primary location does not expect to
receive many updates to the part after a rebalance, this change mainly
effects handoff reversion.  When an object server is accepting writes as
a handoff it's replicator daemon is also trying to remove the partition
from the node after syncing it to the primaries.  If it receives a write
for a new suffix while syncing it will not remove the partition.  If it
is using ssync and receives a write for a different object (hash) while
syncing it will not remove the partition, but an update to a
successfully synced object may still be subject to a race
(clean_suffixes goes object by object, but still uses rmtree without
respect the synced timestamps).

After syncing and removing all suffixes in the partition, the
object-replicator will wait until the subsequent pass to remove the
hashes.pkl, the .lock file, and the otherwise empty partition dir with
rmtree.

Also cleanup the ssync interface for remote check jobs during efficient
cross region replication.

Closes bug #1408061

Change-Id: I40d107c567f02e219f04b1a74d7060f5280432d5

commit_message:
Make probetest validation work for EC

The __main__ in probe.common has historically supported a quick validation of
configured storage policies suitability for replication tests.  The new base
ProbeTest classes will select (or Skip) the test cases based on their ability
to find a suitable policy - but it won't tell you which policies are
configured that would be suitable - the __main__ in common can though.

Also make sure policy validation will use configuration of the replication
services to validate rsync endpoints.  This is a first step and making
probetests support seperate replication servers.

Change-Id: I2f1d5e0e805c052a396d6975bb43cc64994000d3

commit_message:
Catch file open errors before calling ConfigParser

The ConfigParser.read() does not have a way to distinguish between
syntax issues and file access issues. Fortunately, there is a way
to preserve the low-level error message by using .readfp() instead.

Change-Id: I39304f19d733f6ede1ccae69dd937449b5935e9e

commit_message:
FIX http header size constraint

eventlet.wsgi module contain 2 variable that controlling limit of HTTP
headers:
MAX_HEADER_LINE - limit the size on 1 header (one line).
MAX_TOTAL_HEADER_SIZE - limit the whole headers size.

Our code can configure only MAX_HEADER_LINE through
swift-constrains configuration section of swift.conf. This change set both
MAX_HEADER_LINE and MAX_TOTAL_HEADER_SIZE to our "max_header_size"
constraint.

Change-Id: I0fba3360892051720affe343d0b71aaa6edfed6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/64/197764/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: wsgi.MAX_TOTAL_HEADER_SIZE = constraints.MAX_HEADER_SIZE

subject: Better storage server eventlet logging
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-15 00:25:41.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/base_storage_server.py', 'swift/obj/server.py', 'test/unit/account/test_server.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_server.py', 'swift/account/server.py', 'test/unit/container/test_server.py', 'swift/common/wsgi.py', 'doc/source/logs.rst', 'test/unit/common/test_wsgi.py', 'swift/container/server.py', 'swift/common/utils.py', 'test/unit/common/test_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5d462928b466ace4f4b35b49709c4da5f97bc5f5', 'message': 'Better storage server eventlet logging

The eventlet hub can be finicky - she doesn't like it when someone else is in
the spotlight (i.e. blocks).  When she's in a mood like this, sometimes she
won't hand accepted connections to the application as quickly as they're
accepted and you see a request log line from a storage server indicating the
response was "handled quickly" well after the proxy hit a timeout and moved
onto another server.  When this happens it's because the eventlet hub is being
starved by blocking operations in the app, but there's little insight into how
much impact this blocking is effecting the server's response time.

Refactor more common request routing into the base_storage_server.  Add
contextual start time to the WSGI environment captured closer to when the
eventlet.wsgi.server's accept returns a new connection.  Log something closer
to the real transaction time in the storage server logs in addition to the
time the request was "in" our app.

More often that not the logged trans_time will be only nominally longer than
the request_time - but when the eventlet hub is starved because of other
blocking operations it can be notably different.

Change-Id: Id1ee9551196b175d542b0990dff03d00c3c3a6b8
'}]
commit_message:
Better storage server eventlet logging

The eventlet hub can be finicky - she doesn't like it when someone else is in
the spotlight (i.e. blocks).  When she's in a mood like this, sometimes she
won't hand accepted connections to the application as quickly as they're
accepted and you see a request log line from a storage server indicating the
response was "handled quickly" well after the proxy hit a timeout and moved
onto another server.  When this happens it's because the eventlet hub is being
starved by blocking operations in the app, but there's little insight into how
much impact this blocking is effecting the server's response time.

Refactor more common request routing into the base_storage_server.  Add
contextual start time to the WSGI environment captured closer to when the
eventlet.wsgi.server's accept returns a new connection.  Log something closer
to the real transaction time in the storage server logs in addition to the
time the request was "in" our app.

More often that not the logged trans_time will be only nominally longer than
the request_time - but when the eventlet hub is starved because of other
blocking operations it can be notably different.

Change-Id: Id1ee9551196b175d542b0990dff03d00c3c3a6b8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/22/173622/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: trans_time = 1.2 '/sda1/p/a/c/o" 200 - "-" "-" "-" 1.2000 "some information" 1234 -' utils.get_log_line(req, res, trans_time, additional_info))

commit_message:
Fix the Upload an object to a pseudo-folder

Avoiding upload an empty object to a folder.
Wrong: swift upload container/folder obj
Correct: swift upload container/folder/ obj

Change-Id: Icd9f4283686e156692e80419ea8fa0266ec81494
Closes-Bug: #1432734

be a recent-ish version too.

commit_message:
Initial implementation for the storlets spec

This new middleware for Openstack Swift allows to
dynamically add compute functions along the pipeline,
without needing to explicitly add new middleware.

This implementation handles both the PUT and GET
requests, including the GET SLO case.

The class StorletGatewayBase in
swift/common/middleware/storlet_common.py defines
the interface which separates the swift side from
the compute engine side.
This initial implementation uses a stub gateway
implementation.

A code reference with a real (docker) implementation
can be found at:
https://github.com/Open-I-Beam/swift-storlets

*NOT* included in this initial patch and left for
amendment(s):
1.  the Unit tests
2.  The spec reviewer's suggestions/requirements

The spec is at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/164537/

First amendment done for fixing pep8 problems
Amendment2: further pep8 fixes. learnt to use "tox -v -epep8" and not "pep8"...

Change-Id: Ic129e922aed14133316199a0e59de04a03de49e7

commit_message:
Add object undelete spec

Change-Id: I8be7283575b3d0166f68a8b17c5375cf1bbd4435
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift-specs refs/changes/21/155421/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================= Object undeletion ================= This document describes options to and modifications to Swift to cancel DELETE requests. Swift currently has no protection from defective or incorrect usage, for example buggy external applications that delete a lot of objects within a short timeframe or absused account credentials. If someone gets access to valid credentials (either username/password or valid tokens) it is possible to abuse these and DELETE data on the cluster, and there is currently no option to reverse this operation. Object versioning and expiration -------------------------------- Both options are user-configurable, and thus still affected if credentials are abused. The proposed solution should be a cluster-wide setting that is only enabled/disabled by an operator to make it impossible to disable it by abusing credentials. Option 1 -------- The first possible solution is to delay the deletion of object files. The actual .data/.meta file deletion is replaced with a rename, and the "deleted" object is stored in a second subdirectory "deleted_objects" (instead of "objects"). Only the last version is kept, and there is no replication for these files. Either an external (running find by cron) or internal process (object-reaper?) removes these files periodically (for example after 24 hours). A possible drawback is that a rebalance might move the partition with the actual live data to another disk or node, and undeleting the data becomes much more difficult (because it can't be found easily). Option 2 -------- The second option is to modify the method `hash_cleanup_listdir` in DiskFile. This methods cleans object directories and removes all but the newest data. If an object is deleted a tombstone file is placed in the directory, and the older .data files are removed. Replicating the tombstone file makes sure that replicas on others hosts also delete these data files. This method could be reconfigured to keep more than a single (newest) file. A DELETE request would place a tombstone file in the directory, but the older .data file would be kept for some time, making it possible to recover the object data. This also ensures that deleted data is still replicated until the data is removed finally, and also ensures that data is always stored on the correct node, making it easy to actually retrieve the data. Caveats ------- Both options do not protect from actually putting empty objects and thus overwriting the data. It might be required to use the versioning middleware too, and also refactor it to make it possible to prevent disabling it once set. Cleanup ------- After some retention time the old data needs to be removed, otherwise data would pile up and the cluster would store more "deleted" data than current active payload. Removing of this data could be done by extending existing mechanism, for example the object auditor. Undelete -------- Undelete option should be either operator-only or at least configurable. Undelete itself could be a REST API call, for example a PUT to the object with an additional header.

commit_message:
Adds capability to specify config file

This commit adds a widget that allows for file or direct input of
VDU config values during VNF creation. This will bring VNF creation
via horizon in parity with what is currently available in
python-tackerclient

Change-Id: I828a6f5787484a17b1590e144798e25d00a2bfd9
Closes-Bug: #1493558

commit_message:
Prevent to decode with invalid ec scheme

Basically, we must not deploy overwrite the ec policy scheme
if we have already have some objects in the policy becuase
absolutely we won't be able to get the correct data from the
Swift with the overwritten policy.

However, in the such a case, current Swift would return the garbage
(i.e. decorded but incorrect object) and user might not find the fact
it is the garbase, unfortunately.

To prevent the situation, this patch adds a validation that
the swift could decode the FAs correctly.

TODO: Create validater for other similar stuffs (e.g. ec_segment_size)

Change-Id: I4e4955341f78c3eda68890a75d3a8f59322543ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/95/177195/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: found_obj_schemes = list(set( resp.headers['X-Object-Sysmeta-EC-Scheme'] for resp in good_responses)) if len(found_obj_schemes) > 1 or \ found_obj_schemes[0] != policy.ec_scheme_description: self.app.logger.debug( "Returning 503 for %s; found invalid ec scheme (%s)", req.path, ", ".join(found_obj_schemes)) return HTTPServiceUnavailable(request=req)

commit_message:
change deprecated assertEquals to assertEqual

fix against H234: assertEquals() logs a DeprecationWarning
in Python3.x. use assertEqual() instead.And the same, change assertNotEquals() to assertNotEqual().

Closes-bug: #1489031
Change-Id: I7f91f00e848d1630ec83d9d0b409c4fed6f12a3e

commit_message:
bin directory: :Replace python print operator with print function (pep H233, py33)

'print' function is compatible with 2.x and 3.x python versions
Link : https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105/

Python 2.6 has a __future__ import that removes print as language syntax,
letting you use the functional form instead

Change-Id: I379b47c63fd80b617fe4d5972f1d6a0ebee941c4

commit_message:
go: pass vars to container update

Since we kick container updates out to a background goroutine and let the
request handler return, the vars context can be cleared before GetVars is
called.

That means means it doesn't know what device the request was for when saving
asyncs, and it just dumps it into the device root.

Change-Id: I8fff740fa470b9d5012864ed92c8d0767efcb519

commit_message:
go: CopyN that re-uses buffers

Include an implementation of CopyN that reuses buffers, to reduce pressure on
the GC.  Also clean up Copy with new libraries from go 1.5.

Change-Id: Ie8247aa608b6c472a5e5ffde915637aca10f099f

commit_message:
Updated the neutron l3HA tool to use v3

The change adds Keystone v3 support to neutron l3 ha tool. This
change is needed to ensure that all l3-ha fail overs are
accomplished correctly.

The tool has been updated to skip / support routers that have
already bene setup using the built in neutron L3HA.

This is something that will need to be backported to Kilo

Change-Id: I94f21ff3fa511bc9da6b57cdf847719620818ece
Closes-Bug: #1499708
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2108d7fe03427eb9cb6c52a4edd4755582f05fe7)

added_lines: import keystoneclient.v3.client as kclientv3 import keystoneclient.v2_0.client as kclientv2 from neutronclient.neutron import client as nclientIDENTITY_API_VERSIONS = { '2.0': kclientv2, '2': kclientv2, '3': kclientv3 } for key in ['OS_USERNAME', 'OS_PASSWORD', 'OS_AUTH_URL', 'OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE']: if key not in os.environ.keys(): raise SystemExit("Your environment is missing '%s'") auth_version = os.getenv('OS_AUTH_VERSION', None) if not auth_version: auth_version = os.getenv('OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION', None) if not auth_version: auth_version = 3 kclient = IDENTITY_API_VERSIONS[auth_version] kclient_kwargs = dict() kclient_kwargs['username'] = os.environ['OS_USERNAME'] kclient_kwargs['password'] = os.environ['OS_PASSWORD'] kclient_kwargs['insecure'] = args.insecure kclient_kwargs['ca_cert'] = ca kclient_kwargs['auth_url'] = os.environ['OS_AUTH_URL'] tenant_name = os.getenv('OS_TENANT_NAME') if tenant_name and auth_version != 3: kclient_kwargs['tenant_name'] = tenant_name else: kclient_kwargs['project_name'] = os.environ['OS_PROJECT_NAME'] # Instantiate Keystone client keystone = kclient.Client(**kclient_kwargs) # Instantiate Neutron client qclient = nclient.Client( '2.0', endpoint_url=keystone.service_catalog.url_for( service_type='network', endpoint_type=os.environ['OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE'] ), token=keystone.get_token(keystone.session) ) # Filter routers to not include HA routers return [i for i in resp['routers'] if not i.get('ha') == True] return [r['id'] for r in resp['routers'] if not r.get('ha') == True]

commit_message:
Make a few IP methods private

We're getting close to a 1.0 release, and these methods have terrible
interfaces. They're also not used anywhere. So let's make them private
for now, and if we find a time in the future where we need to expose
them, we can do that.

Change-Id: I357dbc0c2e61a5b9f62bfbd45595992d7eb21909

commit_message:
Create neutron floating ips with server info

When we create a neutron floating IP with server port information,
then we don't need to do a separate attach step.

Change-Id: I7e72545465b5de3962d9721339cfe857a37f7d37

commit_message:
Add API for container create, delete, list, show

This patch adds basic API calls for Containers, as well as the testing
infrastructure necessary to test these API calls.

Also adds some basic testing for Bays and Bay Models.

Change-Id: I7cb5dfbd32695c95a414b8d41aa0aa178fe2472e
Implements: blueprint container-api

The returned result is an object with property 'items' and each item under this is a Container. """ result = magnum.container_list(request) return {'items': [n.to_dict() for n in result]} @rest_utils.ajax(data_required=True) def delete(self, request): """Delete one or more Containers by ID. Returns HTTP 204 (no content) on successful deletion. """ for container_id in request.DATA: magnum.container_delete(request, container_id) @rest_utils.ajax(data_required=True) def post(self, request): """Create a new Container. Returns the new Container object on success. """ container = magnum.container_create(request, **request.DATA) return rest_utils.CreatedResponse( '/api/containers/container/%s' % container['uuid'], container)

This patch fixes two problems with RabbitMQ's SSL/TLS listener.

* When self-signed certificates are used, the CA cert isn't created, but it's
  included with the RabbitMQ server config anyway (bug 1507364).

commit_message:
Additional RabbitMQ SSL fixes

This patch fixes two problems with RabbitMQ's SSL/TLS listener.

* When self-signed certificates are used, the CA cert isn't created, but it's
  included with the RabbitMQ server config anyway (bug 1507364).

* Self-signed certificates are owned by root within RabbitMQ's configuration
  directory and are unreadable by RabbitMQ. User-provided certificates aren't
  affected (bug 1506992).

Closes-bug: 1506992
Closes-bug: 1507364

Change-Id: If4f6a325eea4772f2fad4604785241b67adfaaf6
(cherry picked from commit d7031f954de7d73a96c303aed8b6e1f4441c03b0)

commit_message:
Move session and fixtures to keystoneauth1

in an effort to start consuming keystoneauth1, we can move our
sesssion and fixture code over to use keystoneauth1 instead of
keystoneclient.

Change-Id: Ibcbd588ce2e3d864f87ff1eb6e1c3c071a1e06f6

commit_message:
Make designate record methods private for now

The API for designate is not something we can commit to right now. It
turns out that v1 has Domains and Records and v2 has Zones, RecordSets
and Records. Figuring out an API design that can handle both is not
going to happen before 1.0, so mark the current Record API as private
so that we can add something we can commit to later.

Change-Id: Ia2611f19d04a2d7a51d85ac99f19ed4054972085

commit_message:
Add OS::Sahara::ImageRegistry resource

blueprint sahara-image

Depends-On: I94ac401034787955f0f39caf6fd055339b7be69c
Change-Id: I8928f7d2b5fbcb278ba55c0425e2a562a6d6d763
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/64/222864/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from heat.common.i18n import _ from heat.engine import constraints from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import resource from heat.engine import support class SaharaImage(resource.Resource): """A resource for registering an image in sahara. Allows to register an image in the sahara image registry and add tags. """ support_status = support.SupportStatus(version='5.0.0') PROPERTIES = ( IMAGE, USERNAME, DESCRIPTION, TAGS ) = ( 'image', 'username', 'description', 'tags' ) properties_schema = { IMAGE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _("ID of the image to register."), constraints=[ constraints.CustomConstraint('glance.image') ], ), USERNAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Username of privileged user in the image.'), ), DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Description of the image.'), default='' ), TAGS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _('Tags to add to the image.'), schema=properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING ), update_allowed=True, default=[] ) } default_client_name = 'sahara' entity = 'images' def handle_create(self): self.resource_id_set(self.client_plugin('glance').get_image_id( self.properties[self.IMAGE])) self.client().images.update_image( self.resource_id, self.properties[self.USERNAME], self.properties[self.DESCRIPTION] ) if self.properties[self.TAGS]: self.client().images.update_tags(self.resource_id, self.properties[self.TAGS]) def handle_update(self, json_snippet, tmpl_diff, prop_diff): if prop_diff: self.client().images.update_tags(self.resource_id, prop_diff[self.TAGS]) def handle_delete(self): if self.resource_id is None: return try: self.client().images.unregister_image(self.resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Sahara::Image': SaharaImage }

commit_message:
telemetry: add alarming tests in 'smoke' suite

Testing Alarming is really important when testing Ceilometer, Aodh and
Gnocchi.

Without alarming tests, there is no way to test Aodh in 'smoke' suite.
This patch adds the decorator so Alarming tests are part of 'smoke'
tests.

Change-Id: I74b4f76d94b838e2fa5dbbbaed80d28341327f64

commit_message:
specify runtime environment for scripts

I68200a23c87ceca5a237da13d9549c0aa82f1b8f has changed two scripts
to be executable, but unfortunately, it forgets to specify runtime
environment for those scripts, which will cause error when trying
to run those scripts directly.

This patch adds python environment specification for them.

Change-Id: Ibbcefb671de76146529b9a6e2debfee154a1aaa7

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/51/234551/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Remove duplicates from PROJECTS, but leave a trace of what we saw function dedup_projects { local before local after before=$(mktemp) after=$(mktemp) echo $PROJECTS | tr '[:space:]' '\n' | sort > $before cat $before | uniq > $after if [ -n "$(diff -c ${before} ${after})" ]; then echo "*** \$PROJECTS contains duplicates" echo "---" diff -c ${before} ${after} echo "---" fi rm $before $after PROJECTS=$(echo $PROJECTS | tr '[:space:]' '\n' | sort -u) }

commit_message:
Rescue boots to SMS

Previously, the PowerVM power_on Job was broken for bootmode='sms', so
the rescue flow skipped this step, leaving it to the user to boot to SMS
manually.  The power_on Job now works, so this change set restores the
boot step to the rescue flow.

Change-Id: I71e28dcbb96ae580ac3ebb54582eee9a039b9ae6
(cherry picked from commit 2deaae0fe59abffbca6f7b156bcc805ea4e0e11f)

commit_message:
Switch to post-versioning

No longer mention next version on setup.cfg on stable branch.

oslo.utils 2.6.0 causing tox test to hang.
This forces a specific version of oslo.utils *before* the
requirements are loaded, thus ensuring that 2.6.0 is *not* used.
(This is a temporary fix until oslo.util pushes a new version.)

Depends-On: Ica981756c67902e7fd7bd07ff76c5b679e8e4e2f
Change-Id: I97ec9d17b6a611d888ef007575a29c1811f475c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/49/235149/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
LIO: Let delete_initiator succeed if iqn not found

When performing delete_initiator, this should not
raise an error if it can't find the initiator in
an ACL.  This likely indicates something has
gotten out of sync, but the teardown should be
allowed to succeed.

Closes-Bug: #1506496
Change-Id: I3fa9d2e4a435de7c8ee5b24d419930050af197fe

The 'is_initial_wwpn' was simply looking at the fabric state and task
state.  However, if multiple BDMs were specified on a deploy, this would
cause multiple WWPNs to be generated for the same fabric (because each
would be considered 'initial').

This change set expands the logic to also check if any WWPNs have been
set on the fabric yet.  If so, it is not considered an initial WWPN.

Change-Id: I03767f406e004349015483ef8b696f72c57d8ede
Closes-Bug: 1507774
(cherry picked from commit a5995ffc2d5c4ee91bd045ebb2f0ea6ed0deca8d)

commit_message:
Initial wwpn only valid if no existing WWPNs

The 'is_initial_wwpn' was simply looking at the fabric state and task
state.  However, if multiple BDMs were specified on a deploy, this would
cause multiple WWPNs to be generated for the same fabric (because each
would be considered 'initial').

This change set expands the logic to also check if any WWPNs have been
set on the fabric yet.  If so, it is not considered an initial WWPN.

Change-Id: I03767f406e004349015483ef8b696f72c57d8ede
Closes-Bug: 1507774
(cherry picked from commit a5995ffc2d5c4ee91bd045ebb2f0ea6ed0deca8d)

commit_message:
Clean up policy API tests from test_congress.py

This commit moves all the policy api related tests to
api/test_policy_model.py , thus cleaning up test_congress.py

Change-Id: I464a5d7251838f99878221bec78bd65db1741b34
Partial-Bug: #1398640

added_lines: self.initial_policies = set(self.engine.policy_names()) def test_in_mem_and_db_policies(self): ret = self.policy_model.get_items({}) db = [p['name'] for p in ret['results']] mem = self.engine.policy_names() new_memory = set(mem) - self.initial_policies new_db = set(db) - self.initial_policies self.assertEqual(new_memory, new_db) policy_id = self.policy['id'] ret = self.policy_model.delete_item(policy_id, {}) ret = self.policy_model.get_item(policy_id, {}) # check that deleting the policy also deletes the rules rules = self.rule_api.get_items({}, context={'policy_id': policy_id}) self.assertEqual(0, len(rules['results'])) def test_simulate_with_delta_and_trace(self): context = { 'policy_id': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY } action_rule1 = { 'rule': 'action("q")', } action_rule2 = { 'rule': 'p+(x):- q(x)' } self.rule_api.add_item(action_rule1, {}, context=context) self.rule_api.add_item(action_rule2, {}, context=context) request_body = { 'query': 'p(x)', 'action_policy': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY, 'sequence': 'q(1)' } request = helper.FakeRequest(request_body) params = { 'trace': 'true', 'delta': 'true' } expected_ret = { 'result': [ "p+(1)" ], 'trace': "trace strings" } ret = self.policy_model.simulate_action(params, context, request) # check response's keys equal expected_ret's key self.assertTrue(all(key in expected_ret.keys() for key in ret.keys())) self.assertEqual(expected_ret['result'], ret['result']) self.assertTrue(ret['trace'] > 10) def test_simulate_policy_errors(self): def check_err(params, context, request, emsg): try: self.policy_model.simulate_action(params, context, request) self.assertFail() except webservice.DataModelException as e: self.assertIn(emsg, e.message) context = { 'policy_id': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY } # Missing query body = {'action_policy': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY, 'sequence': 'q(1)'} check_err({}, context, helper.FakeRequest(body), 'Simulate requires parameters') # Invalid query body = {'query': 'p(x', 'action_policy': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY, 'sequence': 'q(1)'} check_err({}, context, helper.FakeRequest(body), 'Parse failure') # Multiple querys body = {'query': 'p(x) q(x)', 'action_policy': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY, 'sequence': 'q(1)'} check_err({}, context, helper.FakeRequest(body), 'more than 1 rule') # Missing action_policy body = {'query': 'p(x)', 'sequence': 'q(1)'} check_err({}, context, helper.FakeRequest(body), 'Simulate requires parameters') # Missing sequence body = {'query': 'p(x)', 'action_policy': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY} check_err({}, context, helper.FakeRequest(body), 'Simulate requires parameters') # Syntactically invalid sequence body = {'query': 'p(x)', 'action_policy': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY, 'sequence': 'q(1'} check_err({}, context, helper.FakeRequest(body), 'Parse failure') # Semantically invalid sequence body = {'query': 'p(x)', 'action_policy': self.engine.ACTION_THEORY, 'sequence': 'r(1)'} # r is not an action check_err({}, context, helper.FakeRequest(body), 'non-action, non-update') def test_policy_api_model_error(self): """Test the policy api model.""" # add policy without name self.assertRaises(webservice.DataModelException, self.policy_model.add_item, {}, {}) # add policy with bad ID self.assertRaises(webservice.DataModelException, self.policy_model.add_item, {'name': '7*7'}, {}) self.assertRaises(webservice.DataModelException, self.policy_model.add_item, {'name': 'p(x) :- q(x)'}, {}) # add policy with invalid 'kind' self.assertRaises(webservice.DataModelException, self.policy_model.add_item, {'kind': 'nonexistent', 'name': 'alice'}, {}) # add existing policy self.policy_model.add_item({'name': 'Test1'}, {}) self.assertRaises(KeyError, self.policy_model.add_item, {'name': 'Test1'}, {}) # delete non-existent policy self.assertRaises(KeyError, self.policy_model.delete_item, 'noexist', {}) # delete system-maintained policy policies = self.policy_model.get_items({})['results'] class_policy = [p for p in policies if p['name'] == 'classification'] class_policy = class_policy[0] self.assertRaises(KeyError, self.policy_model.delete_item, class_policy['id'], {})

commit_message:
hadoop: move scripts from post-install.d to install.d

As also the previous comment on the top of 40-setup-hadoop said, this
was done because the Hadoop v1 RPM was buggy, so it needed to be
installed after the rest of the system is set up.

Since the support for Hadoop v1 has been dropped, the installation of
Hadoop can be done in install.d.

Change-Id: If3b0f8f595d6bf36017e63d331b5c1f7faa532e2

subject: Fix incorrect federated mapping example
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-20 09:24:30.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/mapping_combinations.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/dd3ef9ddd284bd5c6d92ec73029f87275ee3d741', 'message': "Fix incorrect federated mapping example

The documentation didn't provide correct example of a mapping rules with
direct group mapping (with blacklist/whitelist keyword).
This could led users to a major confusion.

The example is now fixed. Additionaly, for clarity and increased
readibility the ``user`` and ``groups``
objects were split into separate ``local`` rules.

Change-Id: Iff343f1ff2829ef282a1314fd07203a435611e70
Closes-Bug: #1507944

commit_message:
Fix incorrect federated mapping example

The documentation didn't provide correct example of a mapping rules with
direct group mapping (with blacklist/whitelist keyword).
This could led users to a major confusion.

The example is now fixed. Additionaly, for clarity and increased
readibility the ``user`` and ``groups``
objects were split into separate ``local`` rules.

Change-Id: Iff343f1ff2829ef282a1314fd07203a435611e70
Closes-Bug: #1507944

commit_message:
Huawei driver handle volume exists error

Currently when we create a volume on an array
where that volume already exists,
there will be an exception. But in fact it should
just go on and doesn't need an exception.

Closes-Bug: #1504718
Change-Id: I13a52e81c1c271ea6728cb4a23717609d95bae69

commit_message:
Add unit test for test_servers_client

We have a plan to migrate service clients to tempest-lib from Tempest.
However, we are not doing enough tests for service clients now.
This patch adds unit test for test_servers_client

(all functions)
